content: "A former Miss North Dakota, who's been working in Iran as a freelance reporter, is being detained in undisclosed location there. 31-year-old Roxana Saberi has reported for NPR, "The NewsHour with Jim Lehrer", and Fox News Channel, among others as the Tehran bureau chief for Feature Story News. Her press credentials were revoked by the Iranian government more than a year ago, but she was being allowed to file short stories until her arrest about a month ago." ++http://www.mediabistro.com/tvnewser/generalities/american_reporter_detained_in_iran_109967.asp?c=rss
reply: "A former Miss North Dakota, who's been working in Iran as a freelance reporter, is being detained in undisclosed location there. 31-year-old Roxana Saberi has reported for NPR, "The NewsHour with Jim Lehrer", and Fox News Channel, among others as the Tehran bureau chief for Feature Story News. Her press credentials were revoked by the Iranian government more than a year ago, but she was being allowed to file short stories until her arrest about a month ago." ++http://www.mediabistro.com/tvnewser/generalities/american_reporter_detained_in_iran_109967.asp?c=rss

title: U.S. Reporter detained in Iran

content: quote: Originally posted by Combatmix: I saw the story, said she was detained for buying wine. I didn't think they had that stuff in a muslim country.... Not everyone in Saudi Arabia or Iran follows the strict interpretation of the religion. I learned this in the mid-1990's after the first Gulf War while waiting in line at the Burger King on Ft. Knox. Apparently, Burger King was a novelty to the Saudis that were training on Ft. Knox......it was a looonnng line. Before the current fanatics in Iran took over, Iran had both a Jewish and Christian minority population and they were both allowed to worship in the country. Their populations have probably diminished.

Knox......it was a looonnng line. Before the current fanatics in Iran took over, Iran had both a Jewish and Christian minority population and they were both allowed to worship in the country. Their populations have probably diminished.

content: While it's unfortunate that she's been "detained" by the Iranian authorities.. I don't see how anyone could have failed to forsee this inevitable outcome. An American, (of Iranian descent), female reporter living in Iran under the Islamic fundamentalist theocracy of the mullahs, with the diplomatic relationship between Iran and the US what it is? Just plain stupid on her part imo...

content: quote: Originally posted by mrmixitup: Idealistic Reporters and Prosthelizing Americans: Proudly supplying our enemy with bargaining chips since 2001!!!! Well, what I find interesting about the Hollywood Actor visit is it is portrayed in the press as altruistic assistance to the Iranian Film Industry. Really, reading between the lines I think it was something more. Actors don't fly to Iran to talk with other actors unless business or future business is involved, IMO. The Reporter, in my opinion was there for furthering their career as thats how the reporting field works these days. Go to a closed country of interest or war zone and get your stories carried as a stringer and then get picked up by a major news service. So I would disagree the Reporter was idealistic....just trying to further their career, IMO.
quote: Originally posted by mrmixitup: Idealistic Reporters and Prosthelizing Americans: Proudly supplying our enemy with bargaining chips since 2001!!!!
